An element of a set is an object belonging to a set.

For ideals $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ in a ring $R$, the product $\mathfrak{a} \cdot \mathfrak{b}$ is defined as $\left\{\sum_{i=1}^{<\infty} a_{i} b_{i} ; a_{i} \in \mathfrak{a}, b_{i} \in \mathfrak{b}\right\}$.
Does the concept of a/an Element of a Set need to be defined for a definition of a/an Product of Ideals to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: To understand whether the concept of an 'Element of a Set' is necessary for defining the 'Product of Ideals', we need to analyze the definition of the 'Product of Ideals'. The definition states that the product of two ideals, \(\mathfrak{a}\) and \(\mathfrak{b}\), in a ring \(R\) is the set of all sums of the form \(\sum_{i=1}^{<\infty} a_{i} b_{i}\), where each \(a_{i}\) is an element of \(\mathfrak{a}\) and each \(b_{i}\) is an element of \(\mathfrak{b}\). This definition inherently relies on the concept of 'elements' of the sets \(\mathfrak{a}\) and \(\mathfrak{b}\), as it specifies that \(a_{i}\) and \(b_{i}\) must be elements of these sets. Without understanding what it means for something to be an 'element of a set', one cannot properly grasp the definition of the product of ideals, because the formation of such a product directly involves combining elements from these sets. Therefore, the concept of an 'Element of a Set' is essential for the definition of a 'Product of Ideals' to make sense.
